articles.headline: JPMorgan Settles Case With S.E.C.
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a $153.6 million accord over charges that the firm misled investors.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a $153.6 million accord over charges that the firm misled investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay $153.6 million to settle federal civil accusations that it misled investors in a complex mortgage securities transaction in 2007, just as the housing market was beginning to plummet, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Tuesday.

articles.headline: Oversight Group Did Not Refer Housing Complaints
articles.snippet: The agency overseeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac failed to refer complaints about possible abuse, a report says.
articles.abstract: The agency overseeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac failed to refer complaints about possible abuse, a report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal agency overseeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the taxpayer-owned mortgage finance giants, failed to refer to criminal investigators and other authorities almost 100 complaints about possible foreclosure abuse and mortgage fraud at the companies over a recent two-year period, according to a report issued late Tuesday by the inspector general of the Federal Housing Finance Agency.

articles.headline: The Deficit, Real vs. Imagined
articles.snippet: The problem with the budget debate is just how many of the cuts fall on a relatively small part of the government.
articles.abstract: The problem with the budget debate is just how many of the cuts fall on a relatively small part of the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans say they won’t raise taxes. Democrats are reluctant to cut Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. So discretionary spending — the roughly 35 percent of government that includes other social programs and the military — will have to be a big part of any deal in coming weeks to raise the debt ceiling.

articles.headline: Roots of Bachmann’s Ambition Began at Home
articles.snippet: Representative Michele Bachmann’s political awakening began with her encounters with the school system when she was a foster mother.
articles.abstract: Representative Michele Bachmann’s political awakening began with her encounters with the school system when she was a foster mother.
articles.lead_paragraph: STILLWATER, Minn. — Nearly two decades ago, a stay-at-home mother and onetime federal tax lawyer named Michele Bachmann felt a spiritual calling to open her clapboard home here to troubled teenage girls.

articles.headline: Cost of Wars a Rising Issue as Obama Weighs Troop Levels
articles.snippet: As President Obama contemplates the U.S. future in Afghanistan, his critics and allies alike are comparing the cost of the war to what is not being spent to bolster the sagging economy.
articles.abstract: As President Obama contemplates the U.S. future in Afghanistan, his critics and allies alike are comparing the cost of the war to what is not being spent to bolster the sagging economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will talk about troop numbers in Afghanistan when he makes a prime-time speech from the White House on Wednesday night. But behind his words will be an acute awareness of what $1.3 trillion in spending on two wars in the past decade has meant at home: a ballooning budget deficit and a soaring national debt at a time when the economy is still struggling to get back on its feet.

articles.headline: Public Unions Take On Boss to Win Big Pensions
articles.snippet: After using their influence and campaign contributions to improve their pay and benefits, government unions are using the same tactics to stave off cutbacks.
articles.abstract: After using their influence and campaign contributions to improve their pay and benefits, government unions are using the same tactics to stave off cutbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: COSTA MESA, Calif. — City council elections in this Southern California city are usually sedate. Hot-button issues include whether libraries should stay open at night. Campaign budgets often don’t top $10,000.

articles.headline: A Start-Up’s Camera Lets You Take Shots First and Focus Later
articles.snippet: The company’s technology allows a picture’s focus to be adjusted after it is taken.
articles.abstract: The company’s technology allows a picture’s focus to be adjusted after it is taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: With an innovative camera due out later this year from a company called Lytro, photographers will have one less excuse for having missed that perfect shot.
